concept.title: Plug-in dependencies
concept.shortdesc: A DITA-OT plug-in can be dependent on other plug-ins. Prerequisite plug-ins are installed first, which ensures that DITA-OT handles XSLT overrides correctly.

draft-comment.author: Kristen Eberlein
draft-comment.p: I'm not entirely happy with this topic as it currently is, but want to move forward with the overall rework.

The original topic was quite a mixture of task, concept, and reference. While it could have been reworked as a task topic, it really was about working with a plugin.xml file, not using an extension point.
I still wonder whether this topic would be better of as a reference topic in the reference section for the topic cluster.

section.p: The require element in the plugin.xml file specifies whether the plug-in has dependencies. Use require elements to specify prerequisite plug-ins, in order from most general to most specific.

If a prerequisite plug-in is missing, DITA-OT prints a warning during installation. To suppress the warning but keep the installation order if both plug-ins are present, add importance="optional" to the require element.
If a plug-in can depend on any one of several optional plug-ins, separate the plug-in IDs with a vertical bar. This is most useful when combined with importance="optional".

example.title: Example: Plug-in with a prerequisite plug-in
example.p: The following plug-in will only be installed if the plug-in with the ID com.example.primary is available. If that plug-in is not available, a warning is generated and the installation operation fails.

example.title: Example: Plug-in that has optional plug-ins
example.p: The following plug-in will only be installed if either the plug-in with the ID pluginA or the plug-in with the ID pluginB is available. If neither of those plug-ins are installed, a warning is generated but the installation operation is completed.
